title: Authors and Citation
text: Michel Lang. Maintainer, author. Patrick Schratz. Author. Raphael Sonabend. Author. Marc Becker. Author. Jakob Richter. Author. Damir Pulatov. Contributor.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Lang M, Schratz P, Sonabend R, Becker M, Richter J (2022). mlr3viz: Visualizations 'mlr3'. https://mlr3viz.mlr-org.com, https://github.com/mlr-org/mlr3viz.
code: @Manual{,   title = {mlr3viz: Visualizations for 'mlr3'},   author = {Michel Lang and Patrick Schratz and Raphael Sonabend and Marc Becker and Jakob Richter},   year = {2022},   note = {https://mlr3viz.mlr-org.com, https://github.com/mlr-org/mlr3viz}, }

title: Visualizations for mlr3
text: Package website: release | dev R package provides visualizations mlr3 objects tasks, predictions, resample results benchmark results via autoplot() generic ggplot2.

title: Visualizations for mlr3
text: Install last release CRAN: Install development version GitHub:
code: install.packages("mlr3") remotes::install_github("mlr-org/mlr3viz")

title: Visualizations for mlr3
text: examples plots can look pkgdown references respective functions.
code: library(mlr3) library(mlr3viz)  task = tsk("iris")$select(c("Sepal.Length", "Sepal.Width")) learner = lrn("classif.rpart", predict_type = "prob") rr = resample(task, learner, rsmp("cv", folds = 3), store_models = TRUE)  # Default plot for task autoplot(task) # Advanced resample result prediction plot autoplot(rr, type = "prediction")

title: Visualizations for mlr3
text: {mlr3viz} styles plots ’s theme theme_mlr3() (heavily influenced ggpubr::theme_pubr() theme) “viridis” color palette. want use different theme color palette, apply autoplot() call color scheme adjustments might need change *_color_* *_fill_* *_*_discrete *_*_cotinuous, depending object visualized. even control, can look source code ggplot2 geoms used internally specific autoplot() call (e.g. geom_point()) called. can apply lines different arguments autoplot() call (similar shown theme_gray() adjustment) overwrite appearance (example point size, line width, etc.).
code: autoplot(<object>) +   scale_color_discrete() +   theme_gray()

title: Convert to 'precrec' Format — as_precrec
text: Converts format understood precrec::evalmod() package precrec.

title: Convert to 'precrec' Format — as_precrec
code: as_precrec(object)  # S3 method for PredictionClassif as_precrec(object)  # S3 method for ResampleResult as_precrec(object)  # S3 method for BenchmarkResult as_precrec(object)

title: Convert to 'precrec' Format — as_precrec
text: object () Object convert.

title: Convert to 'precrec' Format — as_precrec
text: Object created precrec::mmdata().

title: Convert to 'precrec' Format — as_precrec
text: Saito T, Rehmsmeier M (2017). “Precrec: fast accurate precision-recall ROC curve calculations R.” Bioinformatics, 33(1), 145-147. doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/btw570 .

title: Plot for BenchmarkResult — autoplot.BenchmarkResult
text: Generates plots mlr3::BenchmarkResult, depending argument type: "boxplot" (default): Boxplots performance measures, one box per mlr3::Learner one facet per mlr3::Task. "roc": ROC curve (1 - specificity x, sensitivity y). mlr3::BenchmarkResult may single mlr3::Task single mlr3::Resampling. Note can subset mlr3::BenchmarkResult $filter() method (see examples). Requires package precrec. Additional arguments passed respective autoplot() function package precrec. Arguments calc_avg cb_alpha passed precrec::evalmod(). "prc": Precision recall curve. See "roc".

title: Plot for BenchmarkResult — autoplot.BenchmarkResult
code: # S3 method for BenchmarkResult autoplot(object, type = "boxplot", measure = NULL, ...)

title: Plot for BenchmarkResult — autoplot.BenchmarkResult
text: object (mlr3::BenchmarkResult). type (character(1)): Type plot. See description. measure (mlr3::Measure) Performance measure use. ... (): Additional arguments, passed respective geom plotting function.

title: Plot for BenchmarkResult — autoplot.BenchmarkResult
text: ggplot2::ggplot() object.

title: Plot for BenchmarkResult — autoplot.BenchmarkResult
text: theme_mlr3() viridis color maps applied default autoplot() methods. change behavior set options(mlr3.theme = FALSE).

title: Plot for BenchmarkResult — autoplot.BenchmarkResult
text: Saito T, Rehmsmeier M (2017). “Precrec: fast accurate precision-recall ROC curve calculations R.” Bioinformatics, 33(1), 145-147. doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/btw570 .

title: Plot for BenchmarkResult — autoplot.BenchmarkResult
code: library(mlr3) library(mlr3viz)  tasks = tsks(c("pima", "sonar")) learner = lrns(c("classif.featureless", "classif.rpart"),   predict_type = "prob") resampling = rsmps("cv") object = benchmark(benchmark_grid(tasks, learner, resampling))  head(fortify(object)) #>    nr task_id          learner_id resampling_id classif.ce #> 1:  1    pima classif.featureless            cv  0.3376623 #> 2:  1    pima classif.featureless            cv  0.3506494 #> 3:  1    pima classif.featureless            cv  0.3636364 #> 4:  1    pima classif.featureless            cv  0.3246753 #> 5:  1    pima classif.featureless            cv  0.2727273 #> 6:  1    pima classif.featureless            cv  0.3116883 autoplot(object)  autoplot(object$clone(deep = TRUE)$filter(task_ids = "pima"), type = "roc")

title: Plot for Filter Scores — autoplot.Filter
code: # S3 method for Filter autoplot(object, type = "boxplot", n = Inf, ...)

title: Plot for Filter Scores — autoplot.Filter

title: Plot for Filter Scores — autoplot.Filter
code: library(mlr3) library(mlr3viz) library(mlr3filters)  task = tsk("mtcars") f = flt("correlation") f$calculate(task)  head(fortify(f)) #>    feature     score #> 1:      wt 0.8676594 #> 2:     cyl 0.8521620 #> 3:    disp 0.8475514 #> 4:      hp 0.7761684 #> 5:    drat 0.6811719 #> 6:      vs 0.6640389 autoplot(f, n = 5)

what: Plot for Hierarchical Clustering Learners — autoplot.LearnerClustHierarchical
title: Plot for Hierarchical Clustering Learners — autoplot.LearnerClustHierarchical
text: Generates plots hierarchical clusterers, depending argument type: "dend" (default): dendrograms using factoextra package. "scree": scree plot shows number possible clusters x-axis height y-axis. Note learner-specific plots experimental subject change.

title: Plot for Hierarchical Clustering Learners — autoplot.LearnerClustHierarchical
code: # S3 method for LearnerClustHierarchical autoplot(object, type = "dend", ...)

title: Plot for Hierarchical Clustering Learners — autoplot.LearnerClustHierarchical
text: object (mlr3cluster::LearnerClustAgnes | mlr3cluster::LearnerClustDiana | mlr3cluster::LearnerClustHclust). type (character(1)): Type plot. See description. ... (): Additional arguments, passed function factoextra::fviz_dend() package factoextra.

title: Plot for Hierarchical Clustering Learners — autoplot.LearnerClustHierarchical
code: library(mlr3) library(mlr3cluster) library(mlr3viz)  task = mlr_tasks$get("usarrests")  # agnes clustering learner = mlr_learners$get("clust.agnes") learner$train(task) autoplot(learner) #> Warning: `guides(<scale> = FALSE)` is deprecated. Please use `guides(<scale> = "none")` instead.   # diana clustering learner = mlr_learners$get("clust.diana") learner$train(task) autoplot(learner,   k = learner$param_set$values$k, rect_fill = TRUE,   rect = TRUE, rect_border = "red") #> Warning: `guides(<scale> = FALSE)` is deprecated. Please use `guides(<scale> = "none")` instead.   # hclust clustering learner = mlr_learners$get("clust.hclust") learner$train(task) autoplot(learner, type = "scree")

title: Plot for OptimInstanceSingleCrit — autoplot.OptimInstanceSingleCrit
text: Generates plots bbotk::OptimInstanceSingleCrit.

title: Plot for OptimInstanceSingleCrit — autoplot.OptimInstanceSingleCrit
code: # S3 method for OptimInstanceSingleCrit autoplot(   object,   type = "marginal",   cols_x = NULL,   trafo = FALSE,   learner = mlr3::lrn("regr.ranger"),   grid_resolution = 100,   batch = NULL,   ... )

title: Plot for OptimInstanceSingleCrit — autoplot.OptimInstanceSingleCrit
text: object (bbotk::OptimInstanceSingleCrit. type (character(1)): Type plot. Available choices: "marginal": scatter plots x versus y colour points shows batch number. "performance": scatter plots batch number versus y "parameter": scatter plots batch number versus input. colour points shows y values. "parallel" parallel coordinates plot. x values rescaled (x - mean(x)) / sd(x). "points" - scatter plot two x dimensions versus y colour points shows y values. "surface": surface plot two x dimensions versus y values. y values interpolated supplied mlr3::Learner. "pairs": plots x y values . cols_x (character()) Column names x values. default, untransformed x values search space plotted. Transformed hyperparameters prefixed x_domain_. trafo (logical(1)) Determines untransformed (FALSE) transformed (TRUE) x values plotted. learner (mlr3::Learner) Regression learner used interpolate data surface plot. grid_resolution (numeric()) Resolution surface plot. batch (integer()) batch number(s) limit plot . Default batches. ... (): Additional arguments, possibly passed underlying plot functions.

title: Plot for OptimInstanceSingleCrit — autoplot.OptimInstanceSingleCrit
text: ggplot2::ggplot() object.

title: Plot for OptimInstanceSingleCrit — autoplot.OptimInstanceSingleCrit
text: theme_mlr3() viridis color maps applied default autoplot() methods. change behavior set options(mlr3.theme = FALSE).

title: Plot for OptimInstanceSingleCrit — autoplot.OptimInstanceSingleCrit
code: if (requireNamespace("bbotk") && requireNamespace("patchwork")) {   library(bbotk)   library(paradox)    fun = function(xs) {     c(y = -(xs[[1]] - 2)^2 - (xs[[2]] + 3)^2 + 10)   }   domain = ps(     x1 = p_dbl(-10, 10),     x2 = p_dbl(-5, 5)   )   codomain = ps(     y = p_dbl(tags = "maximize")   )   obfun = ObjectiveRFun$new(     fun = fun,     domain = domain,     codomain = codomain   )    instance = OptimInstanceSingleCrit$new(objective = obfun, terminator = trm("evals", n_evals = 20))    optimizer = opt("random_search", batch_size = 2)   optimizer$optimize(instance)    # plot y versus batch number   autoplot(instance, type = "performance")    # plot x1 values versus performance   autoplot(instance, type = "marginal", cols_x = "x1")    # plot parallel coordinates plot   autoplot(instance, type = "parallel")    # plot pairs   autoplot(instance, type = "pairs") } #> Loading required namespace: patchwork #> Loading required package: paradox #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'GGally': #>   method from    #>   +.gg   ggplot2

title: Plot for PredictionClassif — autoplot.PredictionClassif
text: Generates plots mlr3::PredictionClassif, depending argument type: "stacked" (default): Stacked barplot true estimated class labels. "roc": ROC curve (1 - specificity x, sensitivity y). Requires package precrec. "prc": Precision recall curve. Requires package precrec. "threshold": Systematically varies threshold mlr3::PredictionClassif object plots resulting performance returned measure.

title: Plot for PredictionClassif — autoplot.PredictionClassif
code: # S3 method for PredictionClassif autoplot(object, type = "stacked", measure = NULL, ...)

title: Plot for PredictionClassif — autoplot.PredictionClassif
code: library(mlr3) library(mlr3viz)  task = tsk("spam") learner = lrn("classif.rpart", predict_type = "prob") object = learner$train(task)$predict(task)  head(fortify(object)) #>    row_ids truth response prob.spam prob.nonspam #> 1:       1  spam     spam 0.8513514   0.14864865 #> 2:       2  spam     spam 0.9339623   0.06603774 #> 3:       3  spam     spam 0.9339623   0.06603774 #> 4:       4  spam     spam 0.9090909   0.09090909 #> 5:       5  spam     spam 0.9090909   0.09090909 #> 6:       6  spam  nonspam 0.1004750   0.89952503 autoplot(object)  autoplot(object, type = "roc")  autoplot(object, type = "prc")

"sil": Silhouette plot mean silhouette value reference line. Requires package ggfortify. "pca": Perform PCA data color code cluster assignments. Inspired uses ggfortify::autoplot.kmeans.

title: Plot for PredictionClust — autoplot.PredictionClust
code: library(mlr3) library(mlr3cluster) library(mlr3viz)  task = tsk("usarrests") learner = lrn("clust.kmeans", centers = 3) object = learner$train(task)$predict(task)  head(fortify(object)) #>    row_ids partition #> 1:       1         1 #> 2:       2         1 #> 3:       3         1 #> 4:       4         2 #> 5:       5         1 #> 6:       6         2 autoplot(object, task) #> Warning: Factor variables are omitted in plot

title: Plot for PredictionRegr — autoplot.PredictionRegr
text: Generates plots mlr3::PredictionRegr, depending argument type: "xy" (default): Scatterplot "true" response vs. "predicted" response. default linear model fitted via geom_smooth(method = "lm") visualize trend x y (default colored blue). addition geom_abline() slope = 1 added plot. Note geom_smooth() geom_abline() may overlap, depending given data. "histogram": Histogram residuals: \(r = y - \hat{y}\). "residual": Plot residuals, response \(\hat{y}\) "x" residuals "y" axis. default linear model fitted via geom_smooth(method = "lm") visualize trend x y (default colored blue).

title: Plot for PredictionRegr — autoplot.PredictionRegr
code: # S3 method for PredictionRegr autoplot(object, type = "xy", ...)

title: Plot for PredictionRegr — autoplot.PredictionRegr
code: library(mlr3) library(mlr3viz)  task = tsk("boston_housing") learner = lrn("regr.rpart") object = learner$train(task)$predict(task)  head(fortify(object)) #>    row_ids truth response #> 1:       1  24.0 23.72519 #> 2:       2  21.6 19.55954 #> 3:       3  34.7 35.10313 #> 4:       4  33.4 35.10313 #> 5:       5  36.2 35.10313 #> 6:       6  28.7 29.98333 autoplot(object) #> `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x'  autoplot(object, type = "histogram", binwidth = 1)  autoplot(object, type = "residual") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x'

title: Plot for ResampleResult — autoplot.ResampleResult
text: Generates plots mlr3::ResampleResult, depending argument type: "boxplot" (default): Boxplot performance measures. "histogram": Histogram performance measures. "roc": ROC curve (1 - specificity x, sensitivity y). predictions individual mlr3::Resamplings merged prior calculating ROC curve (micro averaged). Requires package precrec. Additional arguments passed respective autoplot() function package precrec. Arguments calc_avg cb_alpha passed precrec::evalmod(). "prc": Precision recall curve. See "roc". "prediction": Plots learner prediction grid points. Needs models stored. Set store_models = TRUE [mlr3::resample]. classification, support tasks exactly two features learners predict_type= set "response" "prob". regression, support tasks one two features. tasks one feature can print confidence bounds predict type learner set "se". tasks two features predict type ignored.

title: Plot for ResampleResult — autoplot.ResampleResult
code: # S3 method for ResampleResult autoplot(object, type = "boxplot", measure = NULL, predict_sets = "test", ...)

title: Plot for ResampleResult — autoplot.ResampleResult
text: object (mlr3::ResampleResult). type (character(1)): Type plot. See description. measure (mlr3::Measure) Performance measure use. predict_sets (character()) type set "prediction". points shown plot? Can subset ("train", "test") empty. ... (): Additional arguments, passed respective geom plotting function.

title: Plot for ResampleResult — autoplot.ResampleResult
text: ggplot2::ggplot() object.

title: Plot for ResampleResult — autoplot.ResampleResult
text: theme_mlr3() viridis color maps applied default autoplot() methods. change behavior set options(mlr3.theme = FALSE).

title: Plot for ResampleResult — autoplot.ResampleResult
text: Saito T, Rehmsmeier M (2017). “Precrec: fast accurate precision-recall ROC curve calculations R.” Bioinformatics, 33(1), 145-147. doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/btw570 .

title: Plot for ResampleResult — autoplot.ResampleResult
code: library(mlr3) library(mlr3viz)  task = tsk("sonar") learner = lrn("classif.rpart", predict_type = "prob") resampling = rsmp("cv") object = resample(task, learner, resampling)  head(fortify(object)) #>    iteration measure_id performance #> 1:         1 classif.ce   0.4285714 #> 2:         2 classif.ce   0.1904762 #> 3:         3 classif.ce   0.4285714 #> 4:         4 classif.ce   0.3333333 #> 5:         5 classif.ce   0.1428571 #> 6:         6 classif.ce   0.2857143  # Default: boxplot autoplot(object)   # Histogram autoplot(object, type = "histogram", bins = 30)   # ROC curve, averaged over resampling folds: autoplot(object, type = "roc")   # ROC curve of joint prediction object: autoplot(object$prediction(), type = "roc")   # Precision Recall Curve autoplot(object, type = "prc")   # Prediction Plot task = tsk("iris")$select(c("Sepal.Length", "Sepal.Width")) resampling = rsmp("cv", folds = 3) object = resample(task, learner, resampling, store_models = TRUE) autoplot(object, type = "prediction")

title: Plot for Classification Tasks — autoplot.TaskClassif
code: library(mlr3) library(mlr3viz)  task = tsk("iris")  head(fortify(task)) #>    Species Petal.Length Petal.Width Sepal.Length Sepal.Width #> 1:  setosa          1.4         0.2          5.1         3.5 #> 2:  setosa          1.4         0.2          4.9         3.0 #> 3:  setosa          1.3         0.2          4.7         3.2 #> 4:  setosa          1.5         0.2          4.6         3.1 #> 5:  setosa          1.4         0.2          5.0         3.6 #> 6:  setosa          1.7         0.4          5.4         3.9 autoplot(task)  autoplot(task$clone()$select(c("Sepal.Length", "Sepal.Width")),   type = "pairs") #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.  autoplot(task, type = "duo")

title: Plot for TuningInstanceSingleCrit — autoplot.TuningInstanceSingleCrit
text: Generates plots mlr3tuning::TuningInstanceSingleCrit.

title: Plot for TuningInstanceSingleCrit — autoplot.TuningInstanceSingleCrit
code: # S3 method for TuningInstanceSingleCrit autoplot(   object,   type = "marginal",   cols_x = NULL,   trafo = FALSE,   learner = mlr3::lrn("regr.ranger"),   grid_resolution = 100,   ... )

title: Plot for TuningInstanceSingleCrit — autoplot.TuningInstanceSingleCrit
text: object (mlr3tuning::TuningInstanceSingleCrit. type (character(1)): Type plot. Available choices: "marginal": scatter plots hyperparameter versus performance. color points shows batch number. "performance": scatter plots batch number versus performance. "parameter": scatter plots batch number versus hyperparameter. color points shows performance. "parallel" parallel coordinates plot. Parameter values rescaled (x - mean(x)) / sd(x). "points" - scatter plot two hyperparameters versus performance. color points shows performance. "surface": surface plot 2 hyperparameters versus performance. performance values interpolated supplied mlr3::Learner. "pairs": plots hyperparameters performance values . cols_x (character()) Column names hyperparameters. default, untransformed hyperparameters plotted. Transformed hyperparameters prefixed x_domain_. trafo (logical(1)) Determines untransformed (FALSE) transformed (TRUE) hyperparametery plotted. learner (mlr3::Learner) Regression learner used interpolate data surface plot. grid_resolution (numeric()) Resolution surface plot. ... (): Additional arguments, possibly passed underlying plot functions.

title: Plot for TuningInstanceSingleCrit — autoplot.TuningInstanceSingleCrit
text: ggplot2::ggplot() object.

title: Plot for TuningInstanceSingleCrit — autoplot.TuningInstanceSingleCrit
text: theme_mlr3() viridis color maps applied default autoplot() methods. change behavior set options(mlr3.theme = FALSE).

title: Plot for TuningInstanceSingleCrit — autoplot.TuningInstanceSingleCrit
code: if (requireNamespace("mlr3tuning") && requireNamespace("patchwork")) {   library(mlr3tuning)    learner = lrn("classif.rpart")   learner$param_set$values$cp = to_tune(0.001, 0.1)   learner$param_set$values$minsplit = to_tune(1, 10)    instance = TuningInstanceSingleCrit$new(     task = tsk("iris"),     learner = learner,     resampling = rsmp("holdout"),     measure = msr("classif.ce"),     terminator = trm("evals", n_evals = 10))    tuner = tnr("random_search")    tuner$optimize(instance)    # plot performance versus batch number   autoplot(instance, type = "performance")    # plot cp values versus performance   autoplot(instance, type = "marginal", cols_x = "cp")    # plot transformed parameter values versus batch number   autoplot(instance, type = "parameter", trafo = TRUE)    # plot parallel coordinates plot   autoplot(instance, type = "parallel")    # plot pairs   autoplot(instance, type = "pairs") }

title: mlr3viz: Visualizations for 'mlr3' — mlr3viz-package
text: Provides visualizations 'mlr3' objects tasks, predictions, resample results benchmark results via autoplot() generic 'ggplot2'. returned 'ggplot' objects intended provide sensible defaults, yet can easily customized create camera-ready figures. Visualizations include barplots, boxplots, histograms, ROC curves, Precision-Recall curves.

title: mlr3viz: Visualizations for 'mlr3' — mlr3viz-package
text: Maintainer: Michel Lang michellang@gmail.com (ORCID) Authors: Patrick Schratz patrick.schratz@gmail.com (ORCID) Raphael Sonabend raphael.sonabend.15@ucl.ac.uk (ORCID) Marc Becker marcbecker@posteo.de (ORCID) Jakob Richter jakob1richter@gmail.com (ORCID) contributors: Damir Pulatov dpulatov@uwyo.edu [contributor]

title: Plot for Learner Predictions — plot_learner_prediction
text: Generates plot mlr3::Prediction single mlr3::Learner single mlr3::Task. classification support tasks exactly two features learners predict_type set "response" "prob". regression support tasks one two features. tasks one feature print confidence bounds predict type learner set "se". tasks two features predict type ignored. Note function wrapper around autoplot.ResampleResult() temporary mlr3::ResampleResult using mlr3::mlr_resamplings_holdout ratio 1 (observations training set).

title: Plot for Learner Predictions — plot_learner_prediction
code: plot_learner_prediction(learner, task, grid_points = 100L, expand_range = 0)

title: Plot for Learner Predictions — plot_learner_prediction
text: learner (mlr3::Learner). task (mlr3::Task). grid_points (integer(1)) Resolution grid. factors, ordered logicals value ignored. expand_range (numeric(1)) Expand prediction range numerical features.

title: Plot for Learner Predictions — plot_learner_prediction
text: ggplot2::ggplot() object.

title: Plot for Learner Predictions — plot_learner_prediction
code: library(mlr3) library(mlr3viz)  task = mlr3::tsk("pima")$select(c("age", "glucose")) learner = lrn("classif.rpart", predict_type = "prob") p = plot_learner_prediction(learner, task) print(p) #> Warning: Removed 5 rows containing missing values (geom_point).

code: predict_grid(learners, task, grid_points, expand_range)

title: Generates a data.table of evenly distributed points. — predict_grid
text: learners list trained learners, learner belongs one resampling iteration task task learners trained grid_points (int): see sequenize expand_range see sequenize

what: Objects exported from other packages — reexports
title: Objects exported from other packages — reexports
text: objects imported packages. Follow links see documentation. ggplot2 autoplot, fortify

title: mlr-org ggplot2 theme — theme_mlr3
text: theme heavily influenced partly based ggpubr::theme_pubr(). theme applied default autoplot() methods mlr3 ecosystem. like want use default ggplot2 theme, can add + theme_gray() autoplot() call.

title: mlr-org ggplot2 theme — theme_mlr3
code: theme_mlr3(   base_size = 12,   base_family = "",   border = FALSE,   margin = TRUE,   legend = c("top", "bottom", "left", "right", "none"),   x.text.angle = 0 )

title: mlr-org ggplot2 theme — theme_mlr3
text: base_size [integer] Text font size. base_family [character] Font family. border [logical] TRUE, adds panel border. margin [logical] FALSE, reduces plot margin(s). legend [character] Specifies legend position. Allowed values one c("top", "bottom", "left", "right", "none"). Default "top". x.text.angle [numeric] Rotation angle x axis tick labels. Default value 0. Use 90 vertical text.

title: mlr-org ggplot2 theme — theme_mlr3
code: library("ggplot2") p = ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +   geom_point(aes(color = gear))  # Default plot p   # theme_mlr3() p + theme_mlr3()

title: mlr3viz 0.5.9
text: CRAN release: 2022-05-25 Plots survival objects moved mlr3proba.

title: mlr3viz 0.5.8
text: CRAN release: 2022-04-04 Compatibility fixes.

title: mlr3viz 0.5.7
text: CRAN release: 2021-10-14 Compatibility fix testthat.

title: mlr3viz 0.5.6
text: CRAN release: 2021-09-14 Compatibility fix mlr3tuning. Fixed position labels barplot PredictionClassif.

title: mlr3viz 0.5.5
text: CRAN release: 2021-08-12 Fixed another bug ROC- Precision-recall-curves (#79).

title: mlr3viz 0.5.4
text: CRAN release: 2021-07-01 Fixed bug ROC- Precision-recall-curves (#72, #75).

title: mlr3viz 0.5.3
text: CRAN release: 2021-03-15 New autoplot LearnerClustHclust.

title: mlr3viz 0.5.2
text: CRAN release: 2021-03-08 New autoplot TuningInstanceSingleCrit package mlr3tuning. Fixed bugs autoplot function BenchmarkResult (#63, #65). Fixed bug autoplot function PredictionClust (#67).

title: mlr3viz 0.5.1
text: CRAN release: 2021-01-27 Fix test solaris.

title: mlr3viz 0.5.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-11-02 New autoplot PredictionSurv. New autoplots learners package glmnet via ggfortify. Fixed ROC PRC plots resampling "holdout" (#54). possible, now show confidence bounds ROC PRC plots (#55). Fixed bug autoplot function TaskDens (#57).

title: mlr3viz 0.4.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-10-05 autoplot.*() functions now also generic S3 plot() sibling (#51). New plots cluster tasks, learners predictions mlr3cluster. Fixed wrong labels boxplots BenchmarkResult.

title: mlr3viz 0.3.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-09-25 Compatibility mlr3 >= 0.6.0.

title: mlr3viz 0.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-08-07 Added plots TaskDens TaskSurv package mlr3proba. Update documentation PredictionRegr (#23) autoplot.BenchmarkResult(): Support learners identical IDs (#19) Fixed bug plot_learner_prediction() (#47)

title: mlr3viz 0.1.1
text: CRAN release: 2020-02-19 New plot: learner prediction objects class ResampleResult. Additionally, helper function plot_learner_prediction() first performs resample() plots result. New plot: residual plot objects class PredictionRegr.

title: mlr3viz 0.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-01-08 Initial CRAN release
